newsitem.title: UK: INSIGHT - T-bonds pin hopes on 109-00 support.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - T-bonds pin hopes on 109-00 support.

text.p: June T-bond futures continued to drift lower in automated trade but would find initial support nearby at 109-00,03 on Thursday, technical analysts said.

"There was a reasonable support area between 109-19 and 109-24 which should have helped yesterday but didn't and that suggests to me it has a bit more downward drift on it," Marc Ostwald, technical strategist at London Bond Broking, said.
He pegged the next support level at an area of congestion around 109-00,03 and said this was likely to be tested.
Daily charts show the market hit a 109-00 high on April 29 before shooting higher
T-bonds were quoted at 109-03 at 1049 GMT, down 7/32.
Ostwald said if the market broke 109-00,03 it would look for support at an old chart high from March 27 at 108-23, and to 108-18, lows on March 24 and 25.
But he expected these levels to contain it in the near term.
"I think people are basically on hold because they know they (T-bonds) might get quite a lot lower if the Fed raises rates next time round," he said.
He said if the market were to reverse direction and head higher it would aim for 110-03, the high of Wednesday.
"At the moment this market is looking for buyers and it's not finding them, so we're going to push down through the various levels until we find some buyers coming in," Ostwald said.

Francoise Skelley, head of global trading technical analysis at Credit Suisse First Boston in London said she saw the recent upmove as corrective. "For me critical medium-term resistance is in the 110-11 to 111-11 band," she said.
She noted the recent high was 110-10. "Where bonds have stopped is where they should have stopped if it's to be a continuation of the downmove."
She saw potential for an acceleration to the downside to 108-16,12.
But she also said the market could get a short-term bounce, in which case 109-21,24 would cap it.
At the short end, September Eurodollars were quoted at 93.820, down 0.020 from Wednesday's settlement in Chicago.
